P: (613)   776 - 1266   www.ferlandassociates.com  info @ferlandassociates.com  Proudly Serving Eastern Ontario Since 2014  OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY  IN - HOME ASSESSMENT  Client Name:   Date of Loss:  Address:   Date of Birth:  Telephone #:  Lawyer:   Firm:  Adjuster:   Insurer:  Claim No.:  Therapist:   Sebastien Ferland OT Reg.(Ont.)   Date of Assessment:  Date of Report:  THERAPIST QUALIFICATIONS:  Mr. Ferland is an Occupational Therapist with over 25 years of experience providing rehabilitation  and expert opinion services in the province of Ontario.   His professional practice began in 1998  when he graduated from the University of Ottawa’s School of   Rehabilitation and began working  as a registered Occupational Therapist in the private sector.   Over the years, Mr. Ferland has  developed his clinical skills and evolved to provide expert opinions in matters of human function  to stakeholders in the autom obile insurance sector, personal injury and family law, the  Workplace Safety and Insurance Board (WSIB), Veterans Affairs and the Long - Term Disability  sectors. His opinions are sought by both plaintiff and defense counsel in the context of resolving  matte rs in personal injury and family law cases. He has been qualified several times as an expert  in his field, providing testimony under oath in FSCO tribunals and cases appearing before the  Ontario Superior Court of Justice.  Mr. Ferland’s practice includes regular contributions to catastrophic designation assessment  teams where he provides opinions related to daily function of individuals suffering from serious  physical, psychological and cognitive impairments.   His assessment s inform multidisciplinary

_____________________________________________________________________________________________  First Name Last Name   Claim #: Referral File Number   Page   2   of   15  team members (psychiatry, orthopedics, neurology, physiatry, psychology, etc.) of injured  client’s daily functional capabilities at home, work and in the community, assisting them in  forming opinions surrounding whether the catastrophic injury threshold is   met.  Mr. Ferland concurrently provides services as a treating Occupational Therapist to clients who  have sustained physical and psychological trauma in motor vehicle accidents. He has extensive  experience in providing care to individuals suffering from chronic   pain, depression, anxiety and  posttraumatic stress, overseeing and directing functional reactivation programs to foster  improvements in function and participation in meaningful activity.  ASSESSMENT PREAMBLE :  SUMMARY OF FINDINGS:  RECOMMENDATIONS:  Attendant Care:  Housekeeping:  Assistive Devices:  Further Occupational Therapy Interventions:  Referral for Other Services:  INFORMED CONSENT STATEMENT:  This therapist has reviewed issues related to consent as per the requirements outlined by the  College of Occupational Therapists of Ontario:  ●   An occupational therapy assessment is to be conducted by this therapist, a registered  occupational therapist with the College of Occupational Therapists of Ontario (COTO).  ●   The assessment has been requested by his legal representative Mr. Frank McNally.  ●   The purpose of this assessment is to assess Mr.   CLIENT ’s current functional status as it  relates to his ability to complete pre - accident activities of daily living.

_____________________________________________________________________________________________  First Name Last Name   Claim #: Referral File Number   Page   3   of   15  ●   The proposed assessment will include: an interview, a physical assessment and also  observations of the ability to complete functional tasks within and around the home as  well as education on safe means of completing activities of daily living if required.  ●   Due to the physical nature of the assessment, pain and fatigue are possible temporary  side effects.  ●   Recommendations may be provided at the conclusion of the assessment.   These  recommendations may include:  o   Occupational Therapy Treatment  o   Assistive Devices  o   Referral to other practitioners  o   Support services  ●   A submission for funding will be submitted to the insurer for any goods and/or services  on an OCF18   –   Assessment and Treatment Plan. The insurer may approve or deny the  plan (in part or in whole).   Should a denial or partial denial occur, an independent  e xamination by another Occupational Therapist may be requested by the insurer. This  may be an in - person assessment or a remote paper - review assessment. Funding for the  requested goods and/or services may ultimately be declined.  ●   Mr.   CLIENT   may choose to participate or decline any or all of the proposed assessment.  ●   A report documenting this assessment will be completed and copies will be provided to  the following parties via secure transmission (fax or encrypted email attachment):  o   Zenith Insurance c/o Kaitlyn Witmeyer, Accident Benefits Adjuster  o   McNally Gervan, c/o Frank McNally, Legal Representative  Following this therapist’s explanation Mr. CLIENT granted informed consent for this therapist to  proceed with the assessment and any subsequent interventions.  DOCUMENTATION REVIEWED:  PRE - ACCIDENT MEDICAL HISTORY:  No medical issues. In good physical and mental health.  Always been independent person right from she was young.   Started life early in Nigeria.  Grew up learning to look after people, her siblings  Came to Canada 2019  Worked as a personal support worker. Was working 80   -   100 hours per month. Chose to go to  school to upgrade with Community Social Worker with Hayzen College.   Did this full - time and  worked part - time (25   -   40 hours per month)  Looked after her 13 and 7 with her husband. Youngest son has asthma. This is improving.  She did all the cooking, cleaning, groceries, looking after the boys.  Older   boy   plays   soccer,   she   would   go   to   his   practices   and   games.  Younger one was in hockey, she would take him everyw weekend for practice.

_____________________________________________________________________________________________  First Name Last Name   Claim #: Referral File Number   Page   4   of   15  Engaged in regular road trips to Montreal, Toronto.  MECHANISM OF INJURY:  Called her husband who told her to call the police. When she said to the other driver she said  she would call the police. She was told she had to go and the client took a picture of the plate  number. So much noise, honking. As the other car had driven   off, she drove home and called  the police (house was a few minutes away).   She had no symptoms immediately after the  accident.  She did not seek medical attention immediately. Went back to her activities (schooll and work).  a few weeks later developed pain in her back and neck. She was starting to use medication over  the counter, reduced her work, her GP. He queried about chang es in her life. Her doctor asked  and was informed about of the accident, validating that some people develop symptoms later.  She was prescribed medication.  Referred for physiotherapy through CBI Health, attending 1   -   2 times per week (does not  remember). Stopped this “long ago”.  OT started after referral from legal. Has had OT for a long time.  Currently:  Revival Rehabilitation Centre  -   Psychotherapy, used to be every two weeks, stopped last year  -   OT, once every two weeks  -   Psychiatrist (does not remember his name), started at the end of last year. Has had one  in - person session and two phone calls  Concussion clinic in 2023?  NATURE OF INJURY:  Based on __ , Mr. CLIENT sustained the following injuries as a result of the subject motor vehicle  accident:  -   Lower back  -   Concussion/Headaches  -   Worst thing is her emotions  -   Neck and shouldertight but not in severe pain.

_____________________________________________________________________________________________  First Name Last Name   Claim #: Referral File Number   Page   5   of   15  Right now it is so hard for me to live my way the way it was planned/anticipated. She  feels worthless, useless, things she never knew she could feel  Anxiety for appointments keeps her up all night.   She didnt sleep the night before this  assessment.  Sometimes wants to stop all treatment. Tired, I don’t want it anymore  Can’t help, can’t do things for her kids. They are growing up fast as a result.  Getting her kids to do things, cannot do it with them.  13 year - old is pretty good but the 7 year - old is a lot to handle in her current state  Sometimes I feel they would be better off with their dad and not having me around  Gets pissed off really easily. She has a very short temper. Wants to be by herself, withdrawn.  \ Relationship is strained.  COURSE OF RECOVERY TO DATE:  CURRENT MEDICAL/REHABILITATION TEAM:  Health  Professional  Name and  Specialty  Date of Last Appointment/  Frequency of  appointments  Outcome of Last  Appointment  Date of Next  Appointment  MEDICATION:  Medication Name   Dosage/Frequency   Purpose  See list  SUBJECTIVE INFORMATION (CLIENT REPORT):  Physical Symptoms:  Pain symptoms are rated on an analog pain scale where 0 = no pain and 10 = intolerable pain .  Symptom/Complaint   Details   Pain Rating  if Necessary  Lower back pain   Constant pain in lower bilaterally. Some days  better than others. 8/10 on bad days. Good  5   -   8/10

_____________________________________________________________________________________________  First Name Last Name   Claim #: Referral File Number   Page   6   of   15  days 5/10. 8 good days per month. Has had 3  episodes where both her legs go numb. This  has not happened in a few years but she  remains hypervigilient. Worried about falling  in the shower so she uses shower chairs awith  support form her husband  Headaches   Headache is constant and only dulled a bit  with medication.   Emotions play a big role.  When she is stressed she will experience  increased headache pain.  3   -   5/10  Neck and shoulders   Tightness at this time. Now she feels pressure  and numbness. With bad sleep this becomes  more painful.  If she pushes herself too much, she will be down for a week.  The week of the Discovery was down for the whole week.  Cognitive Symptoms:  Mumble with her words most times  Does not remember dates or events, if she’s reminded then she will take some time to remember  Problem solving, relies on her husband.  Unable to multitask. This is highly stressful. She took a long time to shed the “old me”. She was  told to let it go and let someone else do it.   When she is overloaded she has to go into her  bedroom. Gets overstimulated  Will retreat to her bedroom frequently. Typically in the week, part of her therapy, tries to come  downstairs as much as she can. Forces herself to do groceries as part of her therapy (with her  husband)  Dealing with light is an ongoing issue  Organization has been impacted. Needs to accept lifestyle changes.  Emotional Symptoms:  Symptom Management Strategies:  Mr. CLIENT reported making use of the following strategies to manage his symptoms at this time:

_____________________________________________________________________________________________  First Name Last Name   Claim #: Referral File Number   Page   7   of   15  ●   Rest  ●   Activity avoidance  ●   Medication  FUNCTIONAL AND BEHAVIOURAL OBSERVATIONS:  Tolerances, Mobility and Transfers:  Activity   Client Report and Therapist Observations  Sitting and  repositioning  She can sit 20   -   25 minutes with frequent postural changes.  Bed mobility   This is her happy spot. Can lay in bed all day long.  Transfers   Shower transfers assisted by husband. Independent with the rest.  Standing   Standing with pacing 20   -   25 minutes. She has to lean when static standing. 5 minutes  max.  Balance   Static balance assessed using Four - Stage Balance Test, consisting of holding four  different stances for at least 10 seconds each.  •   with his feet together  •   on one foot (right then left)  •   while in a semi - tandem and,  •   while tandem stance.  Walking   Can walk with her dog, 5   -   10 minutes weather permitting. After grocery shops (little  purchases), she will crash.  Stairs   Able in reciprocal stair climbing pattern. With support from handrail and very slow.  Lifting/Carrying   Not lifting loads of any significance.  Kneeling   With signifccant difficulty cannot stay in th exposition.  Squatting/Crouching   Unable  Bending   Able but painful  Reaching   Able but with difficulty.  Fine Motor  Coordination  Finds her hands feel swollen and she has difficulty managing tiny objects.

Lateral flexion   WFL   WFL  Rotation   WFL   WFL  Hip   Flexion   WFL   WFL   No identified limitations.  Extension   WFL   WFL  Knee   Flexion   WFL   WFL   No identified limitations.  Extension   WFL   WFL  Ankle   Dorsiflexion   WFL   WFL   No identified limitations.  Plantar flexion   WFL   WFL  Emotional Presentation:  Cognitive Presentation:  TYPICAL DAY:  Before:  Up 5:30   -   6:00am to get little one ready for his lunch and clothing.  Once they kick - off for school before 9 then she starts her studies.  Has lunch, continue work in afternoon until kids return.  If she had a project, she would do it in late - nights  She had two PSW clients which she saw everyday nightly.

_____________________________________________________________________________________________  First Name Last Name   Claim #: Referral File Number   Page   10   of   15  Would work 5   -   7:30  Would return for bedtime routine with kids.   Return to school and work as late as she had to, a  couple of hours per day.  Went to bed at 10   -   10:30  Current:  Good   day:  Gets up around 6:00 but does not get out of bed. She takes her medication and goes back to  sleep until 9:30 am  Does her morning self - care and goes back bed to lay down, watch television  She will nap in the afternoon 30   -   40 minutes  If nobody is home, no pressure, she stays in her room all day until kids return  Comes downstairs (especially for her young one  She stays with the kids for 40   -   60 minutes  Back upstairs  They used to have sit - down dinners now they have food they purchase from an African store  Most times she eats upstairs.  After dinner will stay upstairs and listen to soothing meditation music  Once she takes her meds, she’s out   -   8:30   -   9:00  Bad day:  Some days for some reason, her back won’t let her sleep even with medication  Gets her angry and anxious, moody  Those days she is withdrawn  Wakes up, stays in bed (husband pressures her to get up and brush her teeth)  Takes her medication, lays in bed  Not in the mood for anything (eating, talk, watching tv, etc.)  When kids come home from school they come to her to say hi and go back downstairs.  BEdtime routine the same.  ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT:  TYPE OF  DWELLING  Two storey townhome  ROOMS   Qty   LOCATION/DESCRIPTION   FLOOR COVERING  Bedrooms   3   Second floor   Wood  Bathrooms   2.5   Two full on second and powder  room on main  Tile

_____________________________________________________________________________________________  First Name Last Name   Claim #: Referral File Number   Page   11   of   15  Living Room   1   Main floor   Wood  Family Room   1   Basement   Carpet  Dining Room   1   Main floor   Wood  Kitchen   1   Main floior  Laundry  Stairs  Basement  Driveway  Description  Yard  description  LIVING ARRANGEMENTS/SOCIAL STATUS:  Marital Status   Married   ☐   Single   ☐   Common Law   ☐   Other   ☐  Living Arrangement  Children  ACTIVITIES OF DAILY LIVING (Pre and Post Accident):  Pre and Post Accident Self - Care Activities:  Shower transfers  Food preparation  Food serving  Dressing lower body  Emotional regulation   -   good day does not need him as much  Bad days he spends the day regulating her emotionally.  Home Management Activities:  5 hours per of housekeeping assistance  Will pace around and pickup some stuff to stay up.  Legend of Ability:  I   –   Independent   A   –   Partial with assistance   D   –   With devices   U   –   Unable   NA   –   Not Applicable  Indoor Tasks   Pre - accident Engagement   Current Engagement

_____________________________________________________________________________________________  First Name Last Name   Claim #: Referral File Number   Page   12   of   15  Meal Preparation   I   –   Mr. CLIENT managed meal  preparation independently.  Dishwashing   I   –   Mr. CLIENT was able to  manage daily dishwashing to  address the limited dishes he  would   produce   throughout  the day.  Groceries/errands   I   –   Mr. CLIENT did not report  any difficultuies accessing the  community   to   obtain  groceries or run errands.   He  was   independent   in   this  regard.  Bathroom cleaning   I   –   Mr. CLIENT was able to  maintain   his   bathroom  environment independently.  Making/changing beds   I   –   Mr. CLIENT reported being  independent in the changing  of his bed linen on a regular  basis as well as making of his  bed daily.   He reported that  he   managed   with   some  discomfort.  Vacuuming   I   –   Mr. CLIENT would use a  vacuum cleaner to maintain  his living environment.   He  would vacuum small areas at  a time to pace this activity.  Sweeping   I   –   Mr. CLIENT reported that  he would sweep on a daily  basis and was able to pickup  piles using a regular dustpan.  Mopping   I   –   Mr. CLIENT was able to  mop   his   floors   on   an   as -  needed   basis   pre - accident.  He would clean small areas at  a time and pace this activity.  Dusting   I   –   Mr. CLIENT reported no  difficulties with dusting pre -  accident.   He   would   dist  surfaces   regularly,   as -  required.

_____________________________________________________________________________________________  First Name Last Name   Claim #: Referral File Number   Page   13   of   15  Tidying   I   –   Mr. CLIENT reported no  difficulty   with   tidying   his  living   environment   pre -  accident.  Laundry   I   –   Mr. CLIENT managed his  laundry   needs   without  difficulty pre - accident.  Garbage Removal/Recycling   I   –   Mr. CLIENT is independent  in   the   management   of   his  garbage and recycling.  \  Outdoor Tasks   Pre - accident Engagement   Current Engagement  Lawn Care   Mr. CLIENT was not primarily  responsible for lawn care pre -  accident.  Gardening   Mr. CLIENT did not garden  pre - accident.  Snow Removal   Mr. CLIENT was not required  to   complete   snow   removal  pre - accident.  Finances/Financial Management:  Shared with husband before  Husband now has taken responsibility for this.  For example yesterday got a call from student loan program seeking payments.  Caregiving Activities:  Mr. CLIENT is not the primary caregiver for any of his children at this time.  Vocational Activities:  Pre - accident Employment Status   Employed part - time  Employer  Job Title/Duties  Hours per week  Comments  Current Employment Status

_____________________________________________________________________________________________  First Name Last Name   Claim #: Referral File Number   Page   14   of   15  Comments  Leisure Activities:  Road trips with family Montreal and Toronto, often meshing work travel with road trip  opportunities.  Watching movies in the cinema for the kids  Go to downtown pubs downtown for evening out  Good network of friends  Community Access:  Longest time out 30   -   45 minutes maximum.  Used to drives for fun and exploring, no longer doing that.  Volunteer Activities:  COLLATERAL INTERVIEW:  iTS BEEN A HUGE CHANGE FROM BEFORE AND AFTER. 180 degrees change. Completely affected  everything. Planning another child (daughter) but accident happened. No more interest.   He  suggested she try to get her Master’s Degree in Social.   Bsc in Business A dministration from  Nigeria. Was planning on leveraging this to get her Social Work Degree.  She is no longer motivated to get out. Beside physical pain, mental health issues has been the  most problemtic. She is very withdrawn. Not getting involved in sugests that would normally  interest her. No interest in talking about back home, travel, not   she is not involved anymore.  Has been reading about suicidal thinking and queried his wife.  Parenting is dishing out instructions to his 7 year - old.   He is very cooperative and will follow  instructions.   He has had to start waking up early to offset. He is supposed to go to work 3 days  per week but has not been able to do so. He missed opportu nities for advancement as a result.

_____________________________________________________________________________________________  First Name Last Name   Claim #: Referral File Number   Page   15   of   15  CLOSING COMMENTS:  This therapist may be contacted through the offices of FERLAND & ASSOCIATES REHABILITATION  INC. at 613 - 204 - 1549 or by email at   ferland@ferlandassociates.com   .  Sincerely,  _______________________  Sebastien Ferland OT Reg.(Ont)  Encl:   Form 1  Cc:   LF  Insurer  An electronic signature was used in order to assist with a timely report. The assessor is in agreement with the content of t he report, and has  provided authorization to utilize the electronic signature .

SYMPTOMS.symptomNotes:
_____________________________________________________________________________________________  First Name Last Name   Claim #: Referral File Number   Page   14   of   15  Comments  Leisure Activities:  Road trips with family Montreal and Toronto, often meshing work travel with road trip  opportunities.  Watching movies in the cinema for the kids  Go to downtown pubs downtown for evening out  Good network of friends  Community Access:  Longest time out 30   -   45 minutes maximum.  Used to drives for fun and exploring, no longer doing that.  Volunteer Activities:  COLLATERAL INTERVIEW:  iTS BEEN A HUGE CHANGE FROM BEFORE AND AFTER. 180 degrees change. Completely affected  everything. Planning another child (daughter) but accident happened. No more interest.   He  suggested she try to get her Master’s Degree in Social.   Bsc in Business A dministration from  Nigeria. Was planning on leveraging this to get her Social Work Degree.  She is no longer motivated to get out. Beside physical pain, mental health issues has been the  most problemtic. She is very withdrawn. Not getting involved in sugests that would normally  interest her. No interest in talking about back home, travel, not   she is not involved anymore.  Has been reading about suicidal thinking and queried his wife.  Parenting is dishing out instructions to his 7 year - old.   He is very cooperative and will follow  instructions.   He has had to start waking up early to offset. He is supposed to go to work 3 days  per week but has not been able to do so. He missed opportu nities for advancement as a result.

MEDICAL_HISTORY.medicalNotes: _____________________________________________________________________________________________  First Name Last Name   Claim #: Referral File Number   Page   3   of   15  ●   The proposed assessment will include: an interview, a physical assessment and also  observations of the ability to complete functional tasks within and around the home as  well as education on safe means of completing activities of daily living if required.  ●   Due to the physical nature of the assessment, pain and fatigue are possible temporary  side effects.  ●   Recommendations may be provided at the conclusion of the assessment.   These  recommendations may include:  o   Occupational Therapy Treatment  o   Assistive Devices  o   Referral to other practitioners  o   Support services  ●   A submission for funding will be submitted to the insurer for any goods and/or services  on an OCF18   –   Assessment and Treatment Plan. The insurer may approve or deny the  plan (in part or in whole).   Should a denial or partial denial occur, an independent  e xamination by another Occupational Therapist may be requested by the insurer. This  may be an in - person assessment or a remote paper - review assessment. Funding for the  requested goods and/or services may ultimately be declined.  ●   Mr.   CLIENT   may choose to participate or decline any or all of the proposed assessment.  ●   A report documenting this assessment will be completed and copies will be provided to  the following parties via secure transmission (fax or encrypted email attachment):  o   Zenith Insurance c/o Kaitlyn Witmeyer, Accident Benefits Adjuster  o   McNally Gervan, c/o Frank McNally, Legal Representative  Following this therapist’s explanation Mr. CLIENT granted informed consent for this therapist to  proceed with the assessment and any subsequent interventions.  DOCUMENTATION REVIEWED:  PRE - ACCIDENT MEDICAL HISTORY:  No medical issues. In good physical and mental health.  Always been independent person right from she was young.   Started life early in Nigeria.  Grew up learning to look after people, her siblings  Came to Canada 2019  Worked as a personal support worker. Was working 80   -   100 hours per month. Chose to go to  school to upgrade with Community Social Worker with Hayzen College.   Did this full - time and  worked part - time (25   -   40 hours per month)  Looked after her 13 and 7 with her husband. Youngest son has asthma. This is improving.  She did all the cooking, cleaning, groceries, looking after the boys.  Older   boy   plays   soccer,   she   would   go   to   his   practices   and   games.  Younger one was in hockey, she would take him everyw weekend for practice.

ENVIRONMENTAL.environmentalNotes: _____________________________________________________________________________________________  First Name Last Name   Claim #: Referral File Number   Page   10   of   15  Would work 5   -   7:30  Would return for bedtime routine with kids.   Return to school and work as late as she had to, a  couple of hours per day.  Went to bed at 10   -   10:30  Current:  Good   day:  Gets up around 6:00 but does not get out of bed. She takes her medication and goes back to  sleep until 9:30 am  Does her morning self - care and goes back bed to lay down, watch television  She will nap in the afternoon 30   -   40 minutes  If nobody is home, no pressure, she stays in her room all day until kids return  Comes downstairs (especially for her young one  She stays with the kids for 40   -   60 minutes  Back upstairs  They used to have sit - down dinners now they have food they purchase from an African store  Most times she eats upstairs.  After dinner will stay upstairs and listen to soothing meditation music  Once she takes her meds, she’s out   -   8:30   -   9:00  Bad day:  Some days for some reason, her back won’t let her sleep even with medication  Gets her angry and anxious, moody  Those days she is withdrawn  Wakes up, stays in bed (husband pressures her to get up and brush her teeth)  Takes her medication, lays in bed  Not in the mood for anything (eating, talk, watching tv, etc.)  When kids come home from school they come to her to say hi and go back downstairs.  BEdtime routine the same.
